content:
y 5
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic or Kotor for short is an amazing game set in an era of the Star Wars universe that is never explored in the movies. In A New Hope Obi-Wan Kenobi says to Luke: “For over a thousand generations, the Jedi Knights were the guardians of peace and justice in the Old Republic. Before the dark times…”. But because Episode 1 starts just before the Clone Wars we never get to see this “more civilized age”. This is where KOTOR comes in! Set thousands of years before the Clone Wars and the fall of the Jedi, Kotor tells a very compelling story that doesn’t mess around. You are a Smuggler with a shady past that is charged with protecting a ship that’s escorting a very powerful Jedi master known as Bastila who years before staged a trap that killed the last evil Sith lord. The ship gets shot down so you, the pilot and Bastila use an escape pod and just barley manage to avoid the ship blowing up on you. The pods crash on a planet called Taris And you find out that the Sith lord had an apprentice that managed to escape Bastila’s trap has the planet occupied and flooded with Sithtroopers, any ships that try to leave are melted down by a Sith field around the planet. Now you and the Pilot of the destroyed ship must find the Jedi master before the Sith do. Along the way you meet some really interesting characters that you can recruit to  help you on your quest such a Twi'lek and Wookie duo that grew up on the streets and stick together to survive. The combat is pretty slow, (it’s kinda like a refined version of Fallout 1 or 2) but you can still manage to get into tense fights where you just barely make it out alive. It’s makes for a very compelling game where there is always something to do and a reason to care. Another cool thing about KOTOR: A Star Wars story is that you don’t really need to be a Star Wars fan to enjoy it! That’s right, unlike most licensed games where they just assume that you’re already familiar with the series *cough*Shadow of Mordor*cough* in Kotor they explain everything you need to know very early on. Besides, most Star Wars fans aren’t very knowledgeable on this era. All in all, this is a must play for Star Wars fans and RPG fans alike.

content:
2015
												 Ignore my low Steam hours, I played this hours on end on the original Xbox port and then on a disc version for PC. This game is incredible. Even if you aren't much of a Star Wars fan or fan of the Extended Universe, I still recommend this game. This was the original game by the great Bioware, and so when you are playing it you might think to yourself "Hey, this is a lot like Mass Effect!" Pros:+++Great Story-I have to say this is one of the most well written stories in a video game ever, in my opinion. Don't let anyone spoil the story for you.  One of the greatest plot twists ever! ++Non-linear gameplay-You choose what planet you go to and in what order in the story.++Great and Memorable Characters-Anyone who has played this game knows how interesting and memorable the characters are; not one person could forget Carth or Bastila.++Fun Turn-Based Gameplay-Very reminiscent of Tabletop RPG's mechanic wise.+Interesting Locations-Some planets return from the movies, but their are plenty of new ones to keep you interested, from a Sith planet haunted by the ghosts of Sith Lords long passed to a planet entirely of water with a few cities here and there.Cons:-Somewhat slow start-Beginning of the game can get quite redundant after a few playthroughs, but still has enough to keep you interested and having fun.-Shows its age graphically-There are mods to fix this, however.Ultimately I give it a 9.9/10. A great experience.

content:
ry 15, 2015
												Here is my review of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic.As a huge Star wars fan it surprises me that it took me so long to play this game. I recently picked it up in the steam christmas sale for like 3 bucks. I played a couple days later to see how good it actually was. to be honest at first I absolutely hated it. the combat style was completely new to me and I had no idea about anything in the old republic era of star wars so I closd the game and didn't play it for another month. I opened it back up convinced that this game was something. I mean most people say that this is the greatest Star wars game ever, let alone rpg ever.I beat this game a couple hours ago and I have to say that this has been the best Star Wars game I have ever played in my life. Number one this game has an insane amount of content in it. I beat the main storyline in about 30 hours. Most games that hae come out recently don't have a storyline this long. The characters in this game are absolutely awesome to learn about and get to know through the game. the game incorporates a kind of moral system where decisions you make in the game effect whether you go to the dark side and go to the light side. This game has a very cool combat system (was you get the hang of it.) It is turn based so most people (at least me) was not used to this type of system. The graphics are very dated yes, but the game is by far playable. I honestly didn't really have a problem with them. But the best part of the game is that it feels completely "star wars" I really did feel as if I was imersed in the world of Star Wars.Now for cons of this game. In my opinion there isn't that many cons. The only ones I can think of is that your "bag" i guess or where you hold items in endless you can hold a million items if you wanted to which is cool but the items aren't very organized which is the con in this case. My other con is that after I beat the game I planned on doing all of the leftover side quests but when I beat it just rolled credits and I wasn't allowed to go back and do other things in the game which kind of annoyed me.My final rating of this game would have to be 10/10.

content:
6, 2014
												You know, every couple years you have one "pearl" in every kind of genre. 2003, BioWare and Obsidian gave us "Knights of the Old Republic" or short: "KotoR"And this game IS absolutly amazing. WARNING: May include spoilers, even though I´ll do my best to keep them out.KotoR plays like 4000 years BBY (for not SW Nerds: Battle Before Yavin, or 4000 years before "A New Hope").Darth Revan and Darth Malak, two heros of the Mandalorian war, a war that could´ve destroyed the Republic, return to the galaxy as new Dark Lord of the Sith. Darth Revan, the leader of the newly "build" Sith army wins one battle after the other, before he´s betrayed by his student Darth Malak, who wants to rule on his own. Now that we know a little bit about this games backstory (which is also included in the game and one central point of the plot), let´s get down to the mainstory.You´re a soldier (or one of two other classes), recruited for duty on the "Endar Spire". While you´re resting, the Endar Spire gets hijacked by the Sith army. You try to fight your way trough the enemy, while you do your best to reach the Jedi "Bastila Shan", an important role in this war because of her "Force Meditation". As you´re unable to find her, you make an emergency landing on the planet "Taris", which is confronted with a sith blockade. On Taris you´re trying to find Bastila and afterwards leave this planet. As soon as you found her (after doing some favors and a veeery terrible first 2-3 hours), you leave Taris and travel to "Dantooine". As soon as you arrive, your Jedi-Training starts and a long journey to save the galaxy begins...Even though KotoR is already 11 years old, it still has some good graphics to offer. Surely there are so animations that look kinda strange or even some textures which look "washed-out", but it´s still a pretty game. You travel to different planets, which all have their individual look. As we´ve seen in BioWares "Dragon Age 2", this isn´t something they´re always able to achive ;) Also, some of the characters faces look kinda mechanic. They have a disturbing lack of emotions, espacially your main character. Yet they´re able to eradicate this by having absolutly professional voice actors. The atmosphere created by a very typical Star Wars score, pretty graphics and  very well written (and spoken) dialogues is intense and believable, espacially as you´re reaching the end. Planets like "Kashyyk" create their own unique flair and are very well translated from the source-material. Especially the dialogues do a good job of delivering story, feels and atmosphere and serve a very wide variaty of emotions. But as we all know, that´s something BioWare has mastered over the years. The character editor is also nice. Even though you don´t have that much influence on the appearance (as you can only decide how your character looks by some different faces, without having much influence on them), but you´re able to build a charater you want through the variaty of stats and attributs. A good and fair skill-system keeps you motivated to level up and the (even though it´s very limited) customization of your weapons will enable you to create a very individual character. I won´t say much about the story, but.. it´s absolutly amazing. I finish this game at least once a year (also KotoR II: TSL, which in my opinion is a little bit better, even though it´s an unfinished game) and I´m still enjoying it. It keeps you motivated to go on, find all this different NPC´s and involves you in a story that (at it´s time) was a amazing thing for the SW franchise. I recommend you to buy this game and enjoy it. I´ratte it with an 8.6/10. It´s a classic. It´s an example for BioWares brilliance. Buy it now and you will have 20 hours of fun in a world that wants to be explored!

content:
5, 2012
												KOTOR (as the cool kids call it) is; put simply; a classic. If you've enjoyed newer BioWare titles such as Mass Effect and Dragon Age, you will enjoy Knights of the Old Republic. Following a battle system very similar to Dragon Age, KOTOR puts you in the shoes of a force sensitive character trying to survive, find his (or her) place in the universe, and deciding between the call of the light side or the pull of the dark side. Of course you've got to save the universe somewhere along the way.This game shines in always giving you the option to CHOOSE how to do things. Will you help that troubled person, or destroy them? Will you show charity, or rob the helpless of what little they have? Whether you are a Star Wars fan or not, this is a must play. Very few games give you an experience like this.The gameplay is no slouch either, with deep customization, party choices, and force powers to train and use. If you're a fan of RPGs, Star Wars, or video games in general, get this!

												The sequel manages to develop this game's lead character in a more meaningful way, than the entirety of this game. The lead character of this game is barely in KOTOR2.That's the difference between Bioware and Obsidian, in a nutshell.The most interesting thing in this game, is how the "love" relationships in this game are developed. Ironically, this is the exact thing that Bioware is slammed for doing these days.And "The Twist" sucked.This game is alright, but KOTOR2 is leaps and bounds better.KOTOR1 is a "Saturday Morning Cartoon" Star Wars game. KOTOR2 is a "Thinking Man['s]" Star Wars game.

content:
er 14, 2014
												Rating 7.5/10Overview: Turn Based RPGThe Good+ The game has a lot of robust options in how you build your character. You start by choosing between 3 classes, soldier, scout or scoundrel. Each class obviously focuses on different aspects of combat. Further in the game you can then choose the Jedi you wish to be: Guardian, Consular or Sentinel. You can fully customize your character how you wish between attributes, skills, feats and jedi powers. All of this leads to many different options and replaybility in how you design your character+The core aspect of the game is that as you can either play as a Jedi that is good or evil. Saving people, being kind and choosing the peaceful solution leads you to the light side while doing the opposite leads you to the darkside. Doing so leads to certain bonuses to your Jedi Powers. Being good means Lightside powers will use less mana and darkside powers cost more and viceversa. I find the system to be very effective because it ties morality choices into gameplay, a feature that seems to be very lacking in today's modern games. +The game supports a solid story that is engaging throughout the entire game. Dialogue is well done although a bit heavy on exposition in the beginning. +As is the case with every Bioware game, the supporting cast of characters are interesting and unique and features some of the best writing in the game. Getting to know your companions and there back stories is one of the highlights of the game. +The game has plenty of interesting sidequests that are fun to play and depending on how you solve them really start to shape your character. I wish there was more ambiguity with the quests because it becomes very obvious which is the good and evil way to solve them. A moral grey area would have made choices tougher to make.+ The game takes place across a series of planets within the Star Wars universe. Each location feels different from the last and has a rich back story that just adds to the authenticity. The AverageCombat in the game is basic, simply select your choice of attack then watch and hope your character can actually connect with a hit. It doesn't feel very engaging especially in the later parts of the game when you become really powerful. The game had many graphical glitches and bugs in certain areas that made it difficult to play.Final boss is frustratingThere are a lot of areas in the game that feel big and empty.The BadThe UI especially navigating to find items in your inventory is a chore and frustrating. The inventory screen is a long list of your items. Finding a specific item can be problematic, for example, if you find a data pad and want to read it, you have to open your inventory scroll through a long list of items until you find it. If you have other datapads in your inventory that you haven't checked yet then you have to check each one until you find the one you're looking for. There are options to filter the list based on specific items but this doesn't fix the overall problem of a bad overall inventory management system. ConclusionI have played this game many times before it came on steam and having it in my library I decided to play it again to see how well it holds up and I was pleasantly surprised. This game feels like the blueprint for Mass Effect as it shares many similarities in its design choices.

er 8, 2014
												Since the original posting of this review there now appear to be more trouble shooting resources than ever before. Steam has also improved refunds. I still do not recommend the steam version from personal experience and have had better success and instant playability with the GoG version on three separate computers.If you don't like trouble shooting this game probably isn't for you.I have found KotOR to be near impossible to play through steam. Some people may not have much trouble starting it but a majority are not able to get this game to run without spending a significant amount of time troubleshooting. The first time two years ago after nearly an hour of trying fixes the game finally ran after character creation. I was about two minutes in  but could not figure out how to progress. Turns out it was bugged. More troubleshooting and I manage to finally get to the next part of the mission only for it to be bugged again. After a few hours I could not get the game at any more playable of a state. One year later I give it another shot and this time I can't even get the first mission to load. Close to four hours of work and I manged to play five minutes of the game.

content:
er 23, 2016
												Alright I have finally put 100 hours into the steam version of this game and countless more back when I had this game on the xbox. About time I leave a review.This game was a massive part of my childhood growing up as I would always play it growing up. I had never really played an RPG style game such as Kotor before and have hardly played any others afterwards and was mainly only interested in the game for its connection to Star Wars. However, rpg experience grew on me and I really enjoyed the turn-based combat and roleplay aspects and would reccommend this game to the rpg fan and/or the casual Star Wars fan.One of the reasons I enjoyed this game and have replayed it many times (and will likely continue to do so) was the story and the characters which were an excellent part of the game.The graphics for this game are not bad despite being from 2003 (ok they are a little dated... but not bad at all)Now the game has been known to have some issues with some minor bugs and crashes and it can sometimes be hard to start the game but there many fixes that can be found on the internet from people who possibly have run into a similar problem that you could experience. Just remember to save often and in different slotsSummary:Story = GoodCharacters = GoodMusic = GoodGraphics = FineReplayability = Hell YeahHope this was helpful :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 28, 2015
												I got this game from my grandma for Christmas when it released. I never really had any experience with RPG games and I was really young but I could understand the dialogue well enough to love it. I'm still very young today but back then, the game felt so epic and HUGE! I felt like each planet would take days to finish when in reality it only took a few hours. This was the only game I would ever play, I had to have replayed it over 40+ times and this isn't an exaggeration! Once KOTOR 2 came out I just had to get it, the game was fun but not as memorable as KOTOR 1. I remember being actually scared at points in this game. When I arrived to Malachor V, I literally was frightened to play it. The atmosphere and music was so grim and well done! Yesterday, I found my original XBOX along with both games, I checked my save files and WOW, did I play a lot of this game. The music is so nostalgic and a masterpiece! I decided to replay both games and it still holds up today as my favorite game of all time! KOTOR will forever be in my heart.﻿ I could write an entire 5 page essay on the game because of so much more I have to say about it. But I'll leave it at this, and I highly highly encourage you to try out this game. It may seem kind of stale to todays standards, but back then, it was next-gen. This was the only game that I played in my childhood, and I probably played it for 4 years straight without ever getting bored of it. Please give this game a chance and even the sequel the same. One other thing I would like to mention is how emotionally invested in the characters you can get into this game. I was attatched to multiple characters and they felt like they were my friends in real life. I haven't ever had this feeling until recently, with the masterpiece "The Witcher 3", and honestly, it's amazing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2015
												KOTOR is a great game with an amazing story and character development as well as solid voice acting. Bioware has been crafting these aspects of games right for a long time. This game also has a stellar sense of environment for its time in regards to the planets you visit: each area has a distinctive and memorable atmosphere and adjoining characters. The music, geography, encounters, and side-quests all make each area an amazing experience on its own.The component that makes this game a must-own and a classic, however, is its story. The fact that you have true agency over certain situations through dialogue is engaging and makes for a unique gaming experience. The parts of the story that you don't have control over still create such a compelling narrative that truly inhibits emotion - something that many games tend to lack.While no one needs another review to confirm that this game is a classic worthy of any and everyone's library, another voice to support is always helpful.

content:
, 2015
												PROS:+Excellent story. By far the best in any video game in my opinion next to the first Deus Ex. Also has a bunch of unexpected and genius twists that kick you in the balls and make you say "What the hell?"+Brilliant yet simple combat system based on the D&D dice roll system.+Lots of customization for you and your crew.+Lovable characters that you actually see develop through in-game dialogue selections(except Juhani)+Decent graphics for a 2003 game.+The planets you visit are diverse and extremely fun to explore.+Large range of weapons and powers+Light side and dark side alignment choices are present (you can be a saint or a ♥♥♥♥, your choice).+Has HK-47, the slyest and murderous son(or droid?) of a gun that you MUST purchase when you're in Tatooine if you want to laugh all the way to your final fight with Darth Malak. Also has Jolee, the sterotypical old black man that makes you crack up at his sarcastic antics.+Mods support, but why modify an already amazing game,CONS:-Lots of bugs.-Pazaak, the most unfair and unbalanced variation of the game Blackjack/21-Podracing gets old.-Juhani, the most emo character in Star Wars history. I half expected her to burst out singing "Crawling."To be honest who gives a damn about the cons. Just get this game if you want to immerse yourself into a 50 hour campaign of lightsaber duels, firefights, well rounded characters(except for you-know-you) and the best Star Wars story, hell even the best story in a video game.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 28, 2015
												I got this game from my grandma for Christmas when it released. I never really had any experience with RPG games and I was really young but I could understand the dialogue well enough to love it. I'm still very young today but back then, the game felt so epic and HUGE! I felt like each planet would take days to finish when in reality it only took a few hours. This was the only game I would ever play, I had to have replayed it over 40+ times and this isn't an exaggeration! Once KOTOR 2 came out I just had to get it, the game was fun but not as memorable as KOTOR 1. I remember being actually scared at points in this game. When I arrived to Malachor V, I literally was frightened to play it. The atmosphere and music was so grim and well done! Yesterday, I found my original XBOX along with both games, I checked my save files and WOW, did I play a lot of this game. The music is so nostalgic and a masterpiece! I decided to replay both games and it still holds up today as my favorite game of all time! KOTOR will forever be in my heart.﻿ I could write an entire 5 page essay on the game because of so much more I have to say about it. But I'll leave it at this, and I highly highly encourage you to try out this game. It may seem kind of stale to todays standards, but back then, it was next-gen. This was the only game that I played in my childhood, and I probably played it for 4 years straight without ever getting bored of it. Please give this game a chance and even the sequel the same. One other thing I would like to mention is how emotionally invested in the characters you can get into this game. I was attatched to multiple characters and they felt like they were my friends in real life. I haven't ever had this feeling until recently, with the masterpiece "The Witcher 3", and honestly, it's amazing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 24
												This is an attempt to make a spoiler free review from a modern perspective for people unsure as to whether to purchase the game and are unfamiliar with it, but it is, of course, my own opinion, and an informed consumer should look at multiple reviews before buying.Gameplay: The game follows a D&D style turn based combat system, which can either be fun or needlessly boring depending on your preference. It is not a very difficult game to beat, either. Most enemies are there for the sake of being there to slow you down and/or give you something to do. Difficult fights that require you to scratch your head and mix up your approach are few and far between. Don't get me wrong, that does not necessarily make this an unenjoyable experience, but those who wish for a challenge will be dissapointed. In between combat you will focus mostly on dialogue (WARNING: there is A LOT of dialogue in this game; if you are not a fan of listening or reading lots of text, it is unlikely that you will appreciate this game very much), though you will probably also be doing quite a bit of inventory management and min-maxing of equipment, too. Skills in this game are usually used to aid in combat or dialogue (i.e. repairing droids to help in fights, using persuade to get more money out of a quest that you were given, etc...) Apart from that there are several optional mini-games but that about sums up what you actually do.NOTE: It's very useful if you go into this game knowing how basic D&D or D20 RPG systems operate so you understand what all the stats mean. You might have some trouble getting a grasp of the systems without knowing anything about that.IMPORTANT NOTE: This game has difficulty running on anything newer than Windows XP. It's probable you'll have to do some troubleshooting to fix issues playing the game, especially with cutscenes.Story and Quests: The main story in KOTOR is good,  but is unlikely to be that life-changing or awe inspiring for anyone, and its big twist can be seen coming for some time if the player has been paying close enough attention to all the dialogue and story thus far. The main plot also begins rather slowly and takes quite a bit of time to develop. This is not the game for the impatient and easily bored. Sidequests typically are, again, good, but not great. There are some real gems in there, though. I mean, it's a Bioware game. Perhaps the biggest strike against it is the binary morality system. You tend to either be the nicest and most compassionate person in the galaxy, or be a psychotic space Hitler. That being said, the game is classic Star Wars in design, so it's likely that is purposeful, but you should still be aware you are unlikely to be morally or ethically challenged or questioned in any way during this game (very much unlike its sequel, KOTOR 2).Characters: I'm giving this its own section because I feel like it deserves it. Optional party member quests and dialogue are a large part of this games overall story. Most party members in KOTOR are not particularly interesting, and it's likely you'll only do the backstories for characters you do find interesting. But most of this is entirely optional, so it doesn't really count as a strike against the game, and is a nice addition.Sound: Music is by Jeremy Soule so of course it's good. It is not classic John Williams, however. Take that as you will. It can either be good or bad.Graphics: Very dated. I don't feel the urge to go into greater detail as you can just look at screenshots above.Aesthetic: It is mostly bright and colorful without overdoing it. Nothing particularly stands out here. It's vibrant where it wants to be vibrant and dark where it wants to be dark. I don't really have anything to compare it to. Again, I recommend just looking at screenshots.Conclusion: It's a very good game, and definitely worth playing if you enjoy this style of combat and are patient enough with the story. You don't even need to be into Star Wars to have a lot of fun with this game.TL;DR: It's a quintessential Star Wars story (albeit a very slow paced one) mixed with D&D style gameplay and sidequests. If that sounds like something you'd like, you will probably enjoy this game. Be aware that if you try to run it on anything newer than Windows XP you can have problems, especially with the cutscenes. You may have to do some troubleshooting to get it to work.

er 29, 2016
												Revan, Bastila, Carth, Mission, Zaalbar, Juhani, HK, Canderous, and Jolee would form the crew of the Ebon Hawk, and together, embark on a journey unlike any other in the Star Wars Universe. One that is a tale of friendship and hope. A saga of darkness and light. An examination of morality and corruption. A study of past sorrows giving way to future joys… all these things and more. Framed by the journeys of Revan, who wanted nothing more than to keep the galaxy and those he loved, safe. Together, the crew would endure the trials of Tatooine’s Dune Sea, uncover the mysteries of the Utopian society of Manaan, trudge through the thick worshyr forests of Kashyyk, and encounter, first hand, the power of the Dark side on the Sith academy of Korriban. Piece by piece, planet by planet, they would complete the Star map. And with it, their destinies as peacekeepers of the galaxyThank you Revan for a beautiful childhood,Thank you Bastila for showing how much the light side of human nature is stronger,Thank you Knights of the Old Republic

content:
ry 22
												Its an old game that requires alot of work to get running these days, many people who review this game negatively for technical problems have not bothered to attempt to fix any issues they encounter. With that in mind here is an honest run down of some things in it.Every character is exposition dump. Every character is a cliche. Every character keeps me smiling.  Its a bioware rpg so i guess ye. Combat system is old dnd ish. Turn based realtime combat. Can be satisfying with the thud of three lasers hitting a single target all at once dropping it instantly. Generally the combat sounds and looks good for its age, cwl dueling animations.In terms of gameplay its very easy to manage and is only a problem on sand ♥♥♥♥♥♥ planet (sry for edge cant spell it) due to level scaling enemies meaning you are swarmed by large numbers of tough asf sandpeople. (do it first)Force powers are cool to use but are comparable to spells u might see in a standard rpg really- Not that they dont appear fitting of star wars- just that the system is the exact same. Nice plot and companions, as well as the Darth Revan ofc being one of the most loved EU characters .  The second game gives us far more ♥♥♥♥♥♥y exposition regarding him that to me is cwl asf. (Is a Starwars Alexander the Great or maybe a starwars Rand al'thor/Matt?). Companions give you that good old exposition dump. However there is plenty of snappy dialogue and plot lines to chase with them. Canderous has some passionate stories for you. Mandalorians have some cool ♥♥♥ ships.If you have played the original dragon age- then expect a similar formula for how the game rolls.Finally- the music in this game is top tier... The opening theme for the game Endar Spire is amazing and the level is maintained from this game to the next. This ties in with the overall star wars atmosphere and universe building. Lots of details are filled by the heavy winded exposition. At the same time the atmosphere/music creates powerful dialogue and moments sometimes.  POTENTIAL SPOILERS "They say the Force can do terrible things to a mind.  It can wipe away your memories and destroy your very identity. "shiiitttttOverall if you are willing to troubleshoot the game or perhaps buy it from GoG, deal with biowarerpgitus, aged graphics and aged battle mechanics you will find an atmosphere that breathes awesome and characters that go down in star wars history as the best!If u want an idea of the emotional music or kick ♥♥♥ music see belowEmotional:

content:
y 25, 2014
												KOTOR. Motha♥♥♥♥ING KOTOR. This game my middle school life bearable, even if I didn't make it off of Taris half the time.First, the negatives. This game will crash. A lot. It was originally for XBOX classic, so compatibility issues run amok on this game. Not so much for the sequal for some reason. Next, your teammate AI is equivalent to a 5-year-old when it comes to enemies, especially if they just come out of combat. If there's a herd of kathak hounds 20 yards out and they're about to die, they're gonna jog the distance and let off a few rounds before it occurs to them they might bleed to death before they pull a trigger any more. The graphics are kinda cruddy, but again, it was made for XBOX classic, so notm uch you can do to help that. As for positives, the lore is a nice bit of fun to sink your teeth in to if you're into that (I know I am), and if you set the difficulty right for your level of badassery, the game can be challenging and fun in it's combat. the skills allow you to tackle problems a multitude of ways, as are expected, but the persuade skill becomes moot fairly quickly when you become a jedi and get access to the force persuade ability.In summation, if you're willing to fight through a few crashes and some crummy graphics, and you're a fan of Bioware RPGs, I recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												KotOR is probably my favorite game of all time, for quite a few reasons. I remember picking it up back in 2003 when I was 8, just because it had 'Star Wars' in the title. Ever since then, I have played this game through numerous times. The game regardless of how you play it, is just plain fun. The graphics are dated, yet they still look pretty decent. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding. The setting and locations in this game are stunning. From the urban cities of Taris, the deserts of Tatooine, to the oceans of Manaan, all of the locations are beautifully done. The characters you meet are diverse and likable. Most are pretty interesting, including npcs. There are plenty of opportunities to walk around and explore or talk to characters off of the beaten path. There are also mini games such as Pazaak and swoop races. The story is intriguing and has many turns. It also has a lot of replayability. There are different conversation choices, different endings, different classes, abilities, weapons, character party, and for the hardcore players no alien subtitles. There are plenty of customization options for the weapons you use, whether you want to be a calm and thoughtful Jedi using lightsabers and the force, or be the smooth talking smuggler using blasters and grenades, you are able to choose the way you want to play. In conclusion, this is probably my favorite game. It has decent graphics that have aged somewhat well. The locations, characters, and story are all well made and great. There are many options for customization and replayability. Also the game is just plain fun. I'd highly recommend it to any Star Wars, sci-fi, or rpg fan.

												Still a great game after all these years, there's only a few real problems I can think of:* Controls are a bit fiddly sometimes. I've gotten stuck on invisible objects, and once somehow got trapped inside a door requiring me to reload a saved game.* The underwater section in Manaan is still horrible. Prepare to spend 5-10 minutes /slowly/ walking across the sea floor while wishing horrible things upon the developers. * The inventory system is a bit of a mess. Maybe it's because I loot everything I come across, but by the end of the game finding anything was a nightmare. Just way too much stuff and not many ways to sort it. Other than that this is still a great RPG 13+ years later. The voice acting is superb and the story is the most well written out of any Star Wars media I've come across. Recommended.

content:
y 2, 2014
												Pretty cool game. I didn't get to play this game around the time it came out so the graphics are a bit dated for me. But the rpg elements are nice, you get to customize your stats (like str, dex, int, etc.), skills (like opening doors, repairing droids, etc.), and feats (which are actions you can do in combat or passives that gives bonus). If you don't want to do all that customizing, you can just auto allocate them in the options. Some items, like armour, lightsabers, and other weapons, are customizable that will increase damage or add effects like a chance to stun your enemy.The story, which is probably why you're here, is pretty good. Side missions are good. You get to choose your conversations when interacting with npcs, some of them can make a difference in the story while others doesn't. Just a warning though, there is a lot of talking in this game and if you try to choose every possible conversation, some of the npcs will just repeat the same information that you got from other npcs.Overall, this ♥♥♥♥ is good. If you're an rpg fan and doesn't mind dated graphics and long conversations, this ♥♥♥♥♥ is for you. I give this game a thumbs up, as you can see up top.

content:
er 28, 2015
												Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.Pros:I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.Cons:In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

content:
ry 20
												I've been a fan of Star Wars for many years, and I've played many of the franchise's games. Some of them provide excellent action ('Republic Commando', 'Jedi Academy'), but none of them are memorable in the way that 'Knights of the Old Republic' is. In fact, the only Star Wars game which I think approaches it in terms of quality is its sequel. The premise of 'KOTOR' is fairly simple: You play a soldier whose mission it is to stop a powerful Sith Lord, and in order to do so you have to find several components of an ancient map. It may sound like a cliché RPG, but on your travels you'll encounter so many interesting people, fascinating stories and incredible quests, you'll never want it to end. I know I didn't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												KotOR is probably my favorite game of all time, for quite a few reasons. I remember picking it up back in 2003 when I was 8, just because it had 'Star Wars' in the title. Ever since then, I have played this game through numerous times. The game regardless of how you play it, is just plain fun. The graphics are dated, yet they still look pretty decent. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding. The setting and locations in this game are stunning. From the urban cities of Taris, the deserts of Tatooine, to the oceans of Manaan, all of the locations are beautifully done. The characters you meet are diverse and likable. Most are pretty interesting, including npcs. There are plenty of opportunities to walk around and explore or talk to characters off of the beaten path. There are also mini games such as Pazaak and swoop races. The story is intriguing and has many turns. It also has a lot of replayability. There are different conversation choices, different endings, different classes, abilities, weapons, character party, and for the hardcore players no alien subtitles. There are plenty of customization options for the weapons you use, whether you want to be a calm and thoughtful Jedi using lightsabers and the force, or be the smooth talking smuggler using blasters and grenades, you are able to choose the way you want to play. In conclusion, this is probably my favorite game. It has decent graphics that have aged somewhat well. The locations, characters, and story are all well made and great. There are many options for customization and replayability. Also the game is just plain fun. I'd highly recommend it to any Star Wars, sci-fi, or rpg fan.

HE HAD THE WHOLE GALAXY AT HIS BECK AND PONY CALL! IT DOESN't MAKE SENSE! The main chick Bastilla is pretty cute though so it's all good.... but not really because I still had major problems with this pile of absolute ♥♥♥♥! 10/10

content:
30, 2015
 ONE OF THE BEST RPGS OF ALL TIME	In short, KOTOR is a legend. A game that you should buy just to witness the story. It has a well deserved place in my TOP10 best games of all time list. Search for TOP10 RPGs of all times and you will see KOTOR there in any list that is worth mentioning.Like all Bioware games, this game  heavily relies on the story. You wake up in a ship that is under attack and from that on try to save your own skin. On the way you meet good friends on different planets who have rich background stories on their own. 3 of the characters in this game found a place in the Most Popular Star Wars Characters of all time list by Lucas Arts Fans. Especially you will have incredible moments with HK-47. There are usually many ways to complete guests and depending on your actions the future of people and even nations change in the end.WARNING. Dont read any spoilers about this game before your first playthrough. There is a moment in the game that is selected The Most JAW BREAKING MOMENT of all time. It is such a moment that made me stop playing the game because of the shock and made me think how that is possible for a week.Fighting is amazing. There are 3 classes which effect your play stile a lot. Soldier is the typical fighter class while others are a little different. You are a jedi but you are allowed to focus on guns with high dexterity. You can queue 3 actions for each character while fighting for an easier management. I remember the easy difficulty was too easy so avoid that unless you are only into the story.I still love the graphics and the soundtrack is a piece of art. Character voices are very well done. I am still inlove with Jennifer Hale as the voice of Bastila Shan and it still makes me smile remember HK-47 saying MEATBAGs.In conclusion if you are a RPG fun, its highly likely that you already bought the game. If not, then this is the game that willl make you a RPG and Bioware fan.  Graphics 88   Music/sounds 95   Gameplay 90   Story 100   Replayability 90   OVERALL 98

content:
y 3, 2016
												It's a solid dungeons and dragons game masquerading as star wars. The base system for this game is quite obviously D20 from character creation to combat.I'll cut straight to my main gripe which admittedly comes from my expectations compared to reality. Not only do blasters have nowhere near the impact they had in the movies (and they retain their clumsy and random nature) but also everyone has swords. At first this is confusing, but when you replace blaster with bow in your mind it starts to make sense. That's because weapon statlines are straight out of D20 analogues. Mechanically this is fine because it creates some balance between melee and ranged, but thematically it just ruins the experience when you just want to blast some thugs and move along.That is not to say that the star wars paintjob is bad: the story and characters are great! I just was dissapointed with how the game played. I recommend it if you're desperate for a star wars RPG and can put up with the combat. I've enjoyed it, but only despite the gameplay rather than for it.

content:

												By far my favorite RPG of all time. Quite literally now when I play an RPG I hold it up to the standards of this game, which isn't usually a good idea because this game isn't easy to beat. I still enjoy playing through it again and again, it just doesn't get old. The story is so filling, it's hard not to get drawn into it. I know some RPG's you have to focus or constantly try to put yourself in the protaganist's shoes, but Knights of the Old Republic does it for you. It opens the door for you, grabs your coat, sits you down on one of the best chairs on earth, hands you a beverage created by George Lucas from up in the cantina in the sky, and tells the best story you've ever heard. Quite literally, if you haven't played this game yet, you're the equivilant of a bantha fodder. Don't know what is? Even more of a reason to play this game. What are you waiting for? Just buy it. You won't regret it.

content:
er 28, 2015
												Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.Pros:I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.Cons:In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

content:
y 30, 2015
												Good story hampered by clumsy mechanics is the simplest way to sum up KOTOR. Having played this again recently I was struck by how terrible the D20 style ruleset is for a Star Wars game. The force is a mysterious energy field, supposedly binding and connecting all living beings. Except sith troopers apparently, who will resist force push at DC 14 unless your wisdom is over 20. Reducing the force powers to simply "wizard spells" is greatly at odds with the narrative of Star Wars and the game suffers for it. This game is the standard Bioware plot (tm). You have a rag-tag band of heroes and villains, you have 4 totally different places to visit each containing a quarter of the plot device and you can be good, evil or slightly sarcastic. Despite the copy paste plot and characters Bioware somehow crammed a lot of Star Wars moments into this game, it also amazingly has a plot twist to rival ESB which was superbly executed. Another hugely annoying aspect is having 9 allies and yet you can only ever adventure with two, leaving most of the team hanging out on the ship. For all its flaws this is still a game worth playing, especially as it sets up the masterpiece that is the sequel.

content:
y 8, 2013
												A game coming from the good days of Bioware, with a deep setting, and a shapeshifting plot. The story is riddled with plot twists, and the game is using a form of D&D in combat, so the D20 still reigns supreme. The visuals fare just fine, and the music is well-placed in the various locations of the game. Sure, there are a few occasional bugs, and some can be quite annoying, which, when combined with the game's above-average combat difficulty, can cause some headaches. But the drawbacks are largely overshadowed by the well-done aspects of the game. If you're a fan of the Star Wars universe or not is unimportant, since an excellent RPG is the same, no matter the setting. Buy it and do the old Bioware justice.

												Set thousands of years before Luke Skywalker leaves Tatooine, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic sets you into a galaxy that is familiar, yet new and exciting at the same time. In fact, it is one of the best RPGs  on the market, and, needless to say, this a game that EVERY self respecting Star Wars fan needs to play. The characters are compelling, and the storyline is one of the best game storylines I have ever played. Even after all the years it has been out, the game still holds up as fun and enjoyable, and still gets multiple playthroughs from me. I cannot speak highly enough about this game. For anybody who wants a gripping and epic Star Wars storyline, this game should be at the top of your list to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2014
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. When this game released many moons ago I was a young teenager. I have never played an RPG before and even worse: I did not know this game was an RPG. Unaware of my ignorance I placed the game into the the disc tray of my Xbox and never looked back. Since the release of the game I have over 1000 hours of play time between the Xbox and PC version. But what makes this game so good?Firstly is the the story. From the first second you feel a level of immersion that I find hard to get with other games. What makes the story even more enjoyable is that each playthrough you can do things differently and experience something new.Character customization has almost everything I could want in a game. While there are restrictions with physical appearance in character creation everything else seems to disregard it. The leveling system is beautiful with enough options that ensure every character you create will be different if you try. I find myself being immersed with the Equip screen as well, sometimes going through my equipment just to see what I will look in various armors/robes.The gameplay itself is satisfying. Using a real time turn based combat system, you rarely feel things are moving slow. While in combat you have the ability to pause the game, if you wish, and issue up four commands for your companions to perform. Experimenting with this can be fun to see what type of damage you can do and how quickly you can kill harder opponents.Overall, I would highly recommend this game for any Star Wars or RPG fan. Knights of the Old Republic is a milestone in gaming and everyone should try to experience what it hast to offer.

												I am now 26 years old, twice as much as I was when I first played this game. I was already impressed with Bioware's Neverwinter Nights at the time, but the hundreds of hours I spent on KotOR really set the bar for all future RPGs for me. Features you love games like Jade Empire, Mass Effect, KotOR 2 and Dragon Age or even Arcanum, The Elder Scrolls and newer Fallouts for were pretty much all introduced to me by KotOR. A great soundtrack, deep companion stories, good/evil choices that make a difference in the storyline, plentiful side-quests, plot-twists, they're all there. This game was certain to become a classic the moment it hit the shelves in the second half of 2003.Definitely among The Essentials.

content:
y 25, 2014
												KOTOR. Motha♥♥♥♥ING KOTOR. This game my middle school life bearable, even if I didn't make it off of Taris half the time.First, the negatives. This game will crash. A lot. It was originally for XBOX classic, so compatibility issues run amok on this game. Not so much for the sequal for some reason. Next, your teammate AI is equivalent to a 5-year-old when it comes to enemies, especially if they just come out of combat. If there's a herd of kathak hounds 20 yards out and they're about to die, they're gonna jog the distance and let off a few rounds before it occurs to them they might bleed to death before they pull a trigger any more. The graphics are kinda cruddy, but again, it was made for XBOX classic, so notm uch you can do to help that. As for positives, the lore is a nice bit of fun to sink your teeth in to if you're into that (I know I am), and if you set the difficulty right for your level of badassery, the game can be challenging and fun in it's combat. the skills allow you to tackle problems a multitude of ways, as are expected, but the persuade skill becomes moot fairly quickly when you become a jedi and get access to the force persuade ability.In summation, if you're willing to fight through a few crashes and some crummy graphics, and you're a fan of Bioware RPGs, I recommend it.

content:
er 28, 2015
												Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.Pros:I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.Cons:In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

content:
ber 9, 2011
												KotOR is a traditional RPG that was released in 2003. I played it for the first time in 2011 and found the graphics and gameplay to be very playable. The battle fighting mechanics might seem a little odd (find some gameplay footage on youtube), but you get used to it very quickly and it starts to feel natural. I found the voice acting to be good, and the story to be very engaging. The game has a solid length (took me around 45 hours to do the main story + all side quests), and some decent replay value as you can play as a light or dark jedi, and choose a character class of soldier, rogue or scout.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												What can i say? This game is absolutely amazing from start to finish.The plot is very strong with some suprising twists which makes it interesting as well.The characters that follow you have their own background, and your companions may trigger an argument making it feel more alive!The combat is turn-based and easy to understand, with the ability to pause in the middle of the battle, giving you time to set up a strategy.Throughout the game, your actions will change who you are alligned with, whether its the dark side or the light, each having their own unique powers giving it some replayability.There are many side quests for you to complete ranging from interrogating to finding missing holocrons, adding a bit of variety.The only downsides that i give to this game are: the autosave sucks a lot, so make sure you save often to avoid any stress.The AI sometimes messes up, whether they block your way, they get stuck and rarely stop attacking and bugs out for a second or two.Overall i give this game a 9.5/10 because it is one of the best star wars games of all time. It has a lot of content for you to explore and learn the universe of star wars, i believe if you can bypass these cons, this game is a perfect 10/10 without a doubt.

												Not only one of the best Star Wars games ever made, but also one of the best games ever made! Memorable characters, engaging story, and over 40 hours of gameplay. The only problem with KOTOR on the PC is the combat, it is very clunky and at times attacks are delayed. Other than that, well worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 11, 2015
												KOTOR I and II are still the best Star Wars rpg's out there. Definitely worth the buy if you love Star Wars, are a fan of the EU, like well done rpg's, and for some of us, some nostalgia factor. Make sure to read the forums if you have issues playing this game off the bat.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 11, 2015
												I remember when I first played this game, when it first hit the market. I love it as much today as I did back then, being a huge fan of Star Wars as it is. If you are a fan, like I am, then that means this game needs to be added to your collection. The story is compelling and draws you in, the game play is old school and fantastic, and you just cant lose when you get to have your own lightsaber.
